titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Davies/Scroggie Collection of Canadian Fur Trade Documents
Davies/Scroggie Collection of Canadian Fur Trade Documents
titlestmt.author: by Diana Smith and Lisa Conathan

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 30, 2019 at 03:01

did.unittitle: Davies/Scroggie collection of Canadian fur trade documents

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The collection consists of printed contracts completed in manuscript between Canadian voyageurs and their outfitters (1801-1821) and other documents relating to the Canadian fur trade, including correspondence, financial papers, and legal documents (1724-1856). Outfitters include M'Tavish, Frobisher & Co., M'Tavish, M'Gillivrays & Co., and the American Fur Company. Destinations include Michilimackinac, Grand Portage, Rainy Lake, Fort William, and "Posts of the Northwest in Upper Canada."

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Davies/Scroggie Collection of Canadian Fur Trade Documents is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Davies/Scroggie Collection of Canadian Fur Trade Documents. Yale Collection of Western Americana, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collections are processed to a variety of levels, depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived research value, the availability of staff, competing priorities, and whether or not further accruals are expected. The library attempts to provide a basic level of preservation and access for all collections, and does more extensive processing of higher priority collections as time and resources permit.

The 1999 Acquisition was processed in 2000, and the contents are listed at the file level in the Collection Contents section, with further details listed in the Appendix. Later acquisitions received a basic level of processing in 2013. Various acquisitions associated with the collection have not been merged and organized as a whole. Each acquisition is described separately in the contents list below, identified by a unique former call number and titled according to the date of acquisition.

Information included in the Description of Papers note and Collection Contents section is drawn from a description written by Alfred Van Peteghem, who collaborated on the book The Development of the Voyageur Contract (1686-1821) published by the Lawrence Lande Foundation for Canadian Historical Research in 1989. In Van Peteghem's descriptions, the outfitter, voyageur, place and date of contract, destination, position, payment, length of contract, and signatures present in each contract are summarized. Peteghem recorded any additions to the contract under the heading "Observations," and included additional research information or noted unusual features of the contracts under the heading "Comments." He also supplied a Lande type for each contract, as a means of correlating the printed form used in the contracts here to the printed forms described in The Development of the Voyageur Contract . The first two letters of the Lande type are a code for the outfitters' name: MF is used for printed forms carrying all incarnations of the M'Tavish, Frobisher & Co. GN is used to indicate that the contract is a generic form, with no company name printed at top. The last two digits reflect the year of printing of the contract. An "h" in parenthesis following the two digits indicates a wintering contract (or hyvernant), and an "h" not in parenthesis following the two digits indicates that the contract was specifically printed for winterers. There are two contracts printed before 1800: one by Joseph Faniant for Francois Lagarde, of St-Ours (number 8 in the appendix), and another also by Faniant for Joseph Pillon (Pilon), of Dautrai (number 9 in the appendix).
Former call numbers: Uncat MSS 259, Uncat MSS 260, Uncat MSS 631, Uncat MSS 840, Uncat MSS 931, Uncat MSS 995, Uncat MSS 1230, Uncat WA MS File Davies.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection consists of printed contracts completed in manuscript between Canadian voyageurs and their outfitters (1801-1821) and other documents relating to the Canadian fur trade, including correspondence, financial papers, and legal documents (1724-1856). Outfitters include M'Tavish, Frobisher & Co., M'Tavish, M'Gillivrays & Co., and the American Fur Company. Destinations include Michilimackinac, Grand Portage, Rainy Lake, Fort William, and "Posts of the Northwest in Upper Canada."

odd.head: Appendix: List of Voyageur Contracts (1999 Acquisition)

row.entry: William W. Matthews (agent for) American Fur Co.
Jos. Carpentier of Faubourg St. Antoine
2 shirts in his outfit rather than the usual 4; received 6 piastres upon signing, another 4 when leaving
This contract is for the American Fur Company (J.J. Astor's),with Matthews acting as agent
William W. Matthews (agent for) American Fur Co.
Louis Osier and Charles Wilburner of Beaucherville (Boucherville)
received 6 piastres upon signing, another 4 when leaving
This contract is for the American Fur Company (J.J. Astor's), with Matthews acting as agent; highly unusual in that thecontract is for two voyageurs rather than two individual contracts
William W. Matthews (agent for) American Fur Co.
Pierre Rocheleau of Côte des Neiges
will have a 'carrot' of tobacco added to the usual equipment;received 10 piastres upon signing, another 15 when leaving
This contract is for the American Fur Company (J.J. Astor's), with Matthews acting as agent
William W. Matthews (agent for) American Fur Co.
will receive same outfit as he received on his previous trip; received 10 piastres upon signing, another 5 when leaving
This contract is for the American Fur Company (J.J. Astor's), with Matthews acting as agent
will receive double the usual equipment; work as a mason, his trade, when so requested; receives 10 piastres on account and will receive another 4 piastres when leaving
David Mitchell, b. ca. 1750, d. 1832, fur-trader, was a member of the Beaver Club of Montreal
Michilimackinac and posts depending upon Michilimackinac
400 livres the first, 450 for the second year
received double the usual equipment, 1 piastre on account, will receive 4 piastres when leaving, and 11 piastres have to be paid to André Bourdeau (a debt) from his wages

This contract is for the Michilimackinac Company. After theamalgamation of the XY Company with the NWC late 1804, Forsyth, Richardson & Co. entered into the partnership of the Michilimackinac Co. In 1807 both partners were granted membership in the Beaver Club
Alexis Courchêne, resident of Chenail du Nord
marks of Alexis Courchêne and of Joseph Faniant
payment made entirely in advance; will be responsible for reimbursing the money if he does not leave when required to do so

on printed form of M'Tavish, Frobisher & Co., Faniant (Fainant, Fainante), agent of the NW Co. here hires a voyageur for his own services. Faniant is mentioned as a foreman in the trade as far back as 1783 with Waddin in the Peter Pond affair and later by Joseph Frobisher in a 1791 letter to Simon M'Tavish
Joseph Faniant (agent) for M'Tavish, Frobisher & Co.
750 livres the first year, afterwards the wages of the trading post where he will be
mark of François Lagarde, signatures of [witnesses] Antoine-Amable Piet, Joseph C. Duvernay jr., and notary Maurice L.D. de Glandons
the voyageur receives double the usual equipment upon his departure, will carry four packs on the return trip, and receives 72 livres on account
unusual in that it is signed by the voyageur, the notary andtwo witnesses
Joseph Faniant (agent) for M'Tavish, Frobisher & Co.
second in the brigade of Faniant
mark of Joseph Pilon, signatures of [witnesses] Antoine-Amable Piet, and Joseph C. Duvernay jr.
the voyageur will carry four packs on the return trip, andreceives 120 livres on account
unusual in that it is also signed by two witnesses; also thatit stipulates the voyageur will be part of Faniant's canoe (canot de maître?)
Louis Belair for Jean-Marie Boucher (agent) for M'Tavish, Frobisher & Co.
mark of Jean-Baptiste Gagnon, signatures of Louis and Joseph Belair, as well as notary Maurice L. D. deGlandons
the voyageur will carry four packs on the return trip, receives double the usual equipment; no money is given on account
unusual in that it is signed by both parties as well as the notary
Louis Belair for Jean-Marie Boucher (agent) for M'Tavish, Frobisher & Co.
mark of Jean-Baptiste Gagnon, signatures of Louis and Joseph Belair, as well as notary Maurice L. D. deGlandons
the voyageur will carry four packs on the return trip, and receives double the usual equipment and 72 livres on account
unusual in that it is signed by both parties as well as thenotary.
Louis Belair for Jean-Marie Boucher (agent) for M'Tavish, Frobisher & Co.
400 livres, will receive an extra 200 livres if required toproceed to Rainy Lake
mark of Jacques Roy, signatures of Louis and Joseph Belair, as well as notary Maurice L. D. deGlandons
the voyageur will carry four packs on the return trip, and receives 240 livres on account

unusual in that it is signed by both parties as well as the notary. Jean-Marie Boucher enjoyed a long and activelife in the fur trade and eventually established a house and store right outside the compound at Fort William where he wasrenowned for his ability to induce the voyageurs to part with their hard-earned funds and even extended credit to them. His house is a permanent part of any plan illustratingthe layout of Old Fort William. (Lande, p. 48).
Jean-Marie Boucher (agent) for M'Tavish, Frobisher & Co.
Louis LeClerc, cabinet maker, of Rivière-du-Loup
Northern posts, except Nipigon and Temiscaming
signatures of Lesieur [witness?] and Ls. Le Claire
the voyageur will carry four packs on the return trip,receives double the usual equipment; and 144 livres onaccount
unusual in that it is signed by the voyageur, rather thanwith his mark. The man is also a tradesman, but thecontract makes no mention that he will be required to workin his trade at the posts
Louis Belair for Jean-Marie Boucher (agent) for M'Tavish, Frobisher & Co.
mark of Samuel Wells, signatures of Joseph and Louis Belair
the voyageur will carry four packs on the return trip,receives double the usual equipment; and 84 livres on account
unusual in that it is signed by both parties as well as thenotary
John Gregory of Berthier, agent (not John Gregory, partner for M'Tavish, Frobisher & Co.

the voyageur will carry six packs on the return trip, receives double the usual equipment; 600 livres on accountand will receive another 200 livres on account the followingautumn (prior to departure). Voyageurs usually carried two packs of 90 pounds per trip; mention is made in the contract when the voyageur is willing to carry four packs of fur, butthis is the first contract where the voyageur agrees to carrysix packs (or 540 lbs!). His wages are also higher than thosefor any other voyageur contract we have ever seen.
listed with "outfit" for 1802, because outfits start in October of preceding year
Jean-Marie Boucher (agent) for M'Tavish, Frobisher & Co.
the rate old (experienced) winterers are paid at the post
signatures of Baptiste Papin, and Louis Barbier and Baptist [sic] Ham [?] as witnesses
the voyageur will carry four packs on the return trip, receives double the usual equipment; and 200 livres on account
unusual in that it is signed by the voyageur
Jean-Marie Boucher (agent) for M'Tavish, Frobisher & Co.
Étienne Charron dit DuCharme, of St-Pierre [Sorel]
mark of Étienne Charron, signatures of Louis Barbier and Baptist [sic] Ham [?] as witnesses
the voyageur will carry four packs on the return trip, receives the usual equipment; and 120 livres on account
Jean-Marie Boucher (agent) for M'Tavish, Frobisher & Co.
Antoine La Pierre son of Pierre (La Pierre), of St-Cuthbert
750 livres the first year, afterwards the rate of the post
the voyageur will carry four packs on the return trip, receives double the usual equipment; and 12 livres on account
Alexis Trempé (agent) for M'Tavish, Frobisher & Co.
750 livres, and afterwards the rate of the post
mark of Augustin Roy, and signatures of Alexis Trempé, as well as Louis Barbier and Baptist [sic] Ham [?] as witnesses
the voyageur will carry four packs on the return trip, receives the usual equipment; and 24 livres on account

unusual in that it is signed by both parties. "Trempé isa foreman who is later mentioned in reference to the secondFranklin expedition. Peter Warren Dease, in letter of 13 May1825 to Robert McVicar writes telling of how he sent Trempé to Great Bear Lake to prepare for Franklin's arrival there." (Lande, p. 52).
Frederick Singer (agent) for M'Tavish, Frobisher & Co.
Joseph Charpentier, of Baie du Febvre
mark of Joseph Charpentier, and signatures of Joseph Le maitre, witness, and Frederick Singer
the voyageur will carry four packs on the return trip, receives the usual equipment; and 200 livres on account
unusual in that it is signed by both parties.
Frederick Singer (agent) for M'Tavish, Frobisher & Co.
Joseph Gauthier, of Baie du Febvre
mark of Joseph Gauthier, and signatures of Joseph Le maitre, as witness, as well as Frederick Singer
the voyageur will carry four packs on the return trip, receives the usual equipment; 96 livres on account, and willreceive another 154 livres at time of his departure
unusual in that it is signed by both parties. "Singer recruited his men from Lormière and St-François which at that time, as today, was a predominantly Mohawk settlement." (Lande, p. 58).
Frederick Singer (agent) for M'Tavish, Frobisher & Co.
Louis Senneville, of Baie du Febvre
mark of Louis Senneville, and signatures of Joseph Le Maitre, witness, and Frederick Singer
the voyageur will carry four packs on the return trip, receives the usual equipment; 96 livres on account and willreceive 154 livres upon his departure
unusual in that it is signed by both parties.
Frederick Singer (agent) for M'Tavish, Frobisher & Co.
mark of Jean-Baptiste Laurence, and signature of Frederick Singer
the voyageur will carry four packs on the return trip, receives the usual equipment; and 400 livres on account
unusual in that it is signed by both parties.
Régis Lorange of Berthier (agent) for M'Tavish, Frobisher & Co.
mark of Pierre Gagnon, signatures of Claude Laurangé [sic] and Pierre-Joseph Théroux
the voyageur receives the usual equipment and 60 francs on account

unusual because signed by both parties. "The last summer at Grand Portage was in 1802. Since the historic depot was located in American territory about 20 miles south of the border on the shore of lake Superior, it was ultimately given up asAmerican territory following the dictates of Jay's Treaty of 1794. As a matter of fact, a few men and a clerk remained stationed there for several years thereafter but more as a point of dissuasion to the XY rivals than as a depot and point of entry to the portage." (Lande, p. 60)
Jean-Marie Boucher (agent) for M'Tavish, Frobisher & Co.
Étienne Charron dit Ducharme of Berthier
the voyageur will carry 4 packs on the return trip, receives the usual equipment and 180 livres on account
marked "Expédon délivrée" (copy delivered). It is also interesting to note that the voyageur was still sent to Grand Portage (see comment to entry above)
Jean-Marie Boucher (agent) for M'Tavish, Frobisher & Co.
Louis Godon (Godoin?) of Ste-Geneviève de Batiscan
return trip during the year 1805, since he is already hired for the outfit of 1804
mark of Louis Godon; signature of jaen mair bouché [sic]
the voyageur receives the usual equipment and has received 200 livres on account
marked "Expédon délivrée" (copy delivered). Unusual (for fairly obvious reasons) in that it bears the signature of Jean-Marie Boucher, the agent.
Jean-Marie Boucher (agent) for M'Tavish, Frobisher & Co.
700 livres for the first year, afterwards the rate of the post where he will be
marks of Charles Chrétien and Jean Bruno, his tutor
the voyageur receives the usual equipment and has received 24 livres on account; his tutor will receive 100 livres upon Chrétien's departure
marked "Expédon délivrée" (copy delivered). Unusual because this contract is for a minor, and that his tutor is to receive part of his wages
Jean-Marie Boucher (agent) for M'Tavish, Frobisher & Co.
François Éno dit Canada of Berthier
second steersman on the Great River, and bowsman inland
600 livres (or 500, corrected in ink, but not clear from text)
the voyageur receives the usual equipment and has received 180 livres on account
Jean-Marie Boucher (agent) for M'Tavish, Frobisher & Co.
François Charron dit Ducharme jr. of St-Pierre de Berthier
the voyageur receives the usual equipment and has received 15 piastres on account
Jean-Marie Boucher (agent) for M'Tavish, Frobisher & Co.
650 livres for the first year, second and third year the rate of the post
the voyageur receives double the usual equipment of a winterer and has received 48 livres on account
Jean-Marie Boucher (agent) for M'Tavish, Frobisher & Co.
"bout de canot" (instead of the usual term, gouvernail, i.e. steersman)
700 livres and if rates increase he will receive the difference
the voyageur receives the usual equipment and 300 livres on account

marked "Expédon délivrée" (copy delivered). See also entrybelow for contract of same date made out to his relative, Louis Sanssouci. Unusual in that it stipulates a possible increase of salary if conditions change.
Jean-Marie Boucher (agent) for M'Tavish, Frobisher & Co.
the voyageur receives the usual equipment and 100 livres on account
Jean-Marie Boucher (agent) for M'Tavish, Frobisher & Co.
second on the Great River, and milieu inland
the voyageur receives the usual equipment and 150 livres on account
Jean-Marie Boucher (agent) for M'Tavish, Frobisher & Co.
second on the Great River, and milieu inland
the voyageur receives the usual equipment and 150 livres on account
Jean-Marie Boucher (agent) for M'Tavish, Frobisher & Co.
Pierre Vilandré son of Antoine, of parish of St-Esprit, Berthier
the voyageur receives the usual equipment and 150 livres on account, and will receive no more until his return
Jean-Marie Boucher (agent) for M'Tavish, Frobisher & Co.
700 livres for the first year, rate of the post where he will be for the rest
the voyageur receives the usual equipment wintering milieus receive and 60 francs on account
Jean-Marie Boucher (agent) for M'Tavish, Frobisher & Co.
Joseph Évrard son of Jean-Baptiste of Ile Dupas
the voyageur receives the usual equipment and 60 livres on account

the voyageur receives the usual equipment for winterers in the Northern posts and 96 livres on account

Northern posts except Nipigon, Fonds du Lac and les Rats

the voyageur receives the usual equipment and has received 100 livres on account
Jean-Marie Boucher (agent) for M'Tavish, Frobisher & Co.
the voyageur receives double the usual equipment and 86 livres on account
Jean-Marie Boucher (agent) for M'Tavish, Frobisher & Co.
Jérémie Bruno, son of the late Jean-Baptiste Bruno, of Maskinongé
the voyageur receives double the usual equipment and has received 90 livres on account
Jean-Marie Boucher (agent) for M'Tavish, Frobisher & Co.
900 livres, afterwards the rate of the post where he will be
the voyageur receives double the usual equipment of a winterer and has received 300 livres on account
Jean-Marie Boucher (agent) for M'Tavish, Frobisher & Co.
700 livres for the first year, the rate of the post where he will be the following year
the voyageur receives double the usual winterers' equipment and 300 livres on account
Jean-Marie Boucher (agent) for M'Tavish, Frobisher & Co.
the voyageur receives the usual equipment and has received 342 livres on account the previous year but was prevented from traveling; will travel this year or return the money advanced
Jean-Marie Boucher (agent) for M'Tavish, Frobisher & Co.
make two voyages from Kaministiguia to Portage de la Montagne
800 livres for the first year, the rate of the post the following year
the voyageur receives double the usual equipment and 30 livres on account
John Gregory of Berthier, agent (not the partner, as no. 17 for M'Tavish, Frobisher & Co.
the voyageur receives the usual equipment and has received 6 piastres on account
John Gregory of Berthier, agent (not the partner, as above, for M'Tavish, Frobisher & Co.
the voyageur receives the usual equipment, no advance
Jean Noël St-Amand of Rivière à la Graisse
the voyageur receives the usual equipment, and an advance of 8 piastres
the name of partner John Gregory is crossed out in the text, and the name of the partnership M'Tavish, Frobisher is changed in Ms. To M'Tavish, M'Gillivray
François Hypolite (Hippolyte) Dufau of Grand St-Esprit
600 livres per annum, if required to work in his trade as mason or carpenter, he will receive 750 per annum, but no breeches the second year
the voyageur receives the usual double equipment, a pair of cloth breeches per annum (except as stated above) and an advance of 10 piastres when leaving
the name of partner John Gregory is crossed out in the text, and the name of the partnership M'Tavish, Frobisher is changed in Ms. To M'Tavish, M'Gillivray
the voyageur receives the usual double equipment, and an advance of 4 piastres
the name of partner John Gregory is crossed out in the text, and the name of the partnership M'Tavish, Frobisher is changed in Ms. To M'Tavish, M'Gillivray
Archibald Norman McLeod, partner, for M'Tavish, M'Gillivrays& Co.
600 livres for the first year, and the rates and conditions of the post for the others
the voyageur receives an advance of 10 piastres; will receive another 10 when leaving
imprint: De l'Imprimerie de Brown. Equipment is detailed as above.
Archibald Norman McLeod, partner, for M'Tavish, M'Gillivrays& Co.
600 livres for the first year, and the rates and conditions of the post for the others
the voyageur receives an advance of 10 piastres and another 10 when leaving

imprint: De l'Imprimerie de Brown. The winterer's equipment is described in the printed contract: a blanket of three points, another of two and a half points, six ells of cotton, one pair of mocassins and a (bead) collar. Thesewere used as trade goods for the personal profit of the voyageur.
Archibald Norman McLeod, partner, for M'Tavish, M'Gillivrays& Co.
"bout" (i.e. steersman, used here instead of the word gouvernail)
400 livres, and additional 200 if he travels to Rainy Lake
the voyageur receives an advance of 25 piastres; will receive another 5 when leaving

imprint: [Montréal] De l'Imprimerie de Brown. "From archivalsources and private collections, we note a flurry of contracting activity during the month of December 1811 and running over into January 1812. This activity was undoubtedly provoked by the visit of William McGillivray to New York in January of 1811 and the resultant formation of the South West Fur Company in copartnership with John Jacob Astor. The outbreak of the War of 1812 in June of 1812 would have rendered much of this activity meaningless as most of the voyageurs would have by then been enlisted in the famous Canadian Corps of Voyageurs. In effect, this outfit, as well as the outfits of 1813 and 1814, would never be." (Lande, p. 80).
Archibald Norman McLeod, partner, for M'Tavish, M'Gillivrays& Co.
300 livres, and additional 200 if he travels to Rainy Lake
the voyageur receives an advance of 15 piastres; will receive another 6 when leaving

the voyageur receives an advance of 10 piastres

the voyageur receives an advance of 20 piastres; will receive another 8 when leaving

Posts of the Northwest in Upper Canada
mark of Joseph La Noix; signed by A.N. MacLeod
the voyageur receives an advance of 10 piastres; will receive 6 when leaving

"The dating of type MF20 is facilitated by the fact that thephrase 'l'an mil huit cent vingt___' is employed ... we judgethis form to have been printed in the fall of 1820. Note thatthe list of named empowered partners is now headed by Williamand Simon McGillivray. The next partner, Archibald Norman McLeod, had by this time become firmly installed, since the tragic death in 1816 of Kenneth Mackenzie, as the Montrealhiring agent of the NWC." (Lande, p. 88).
Archibald Norman McLeod, partner, for M'Tavish, M'Gillivrays& Co.

as above. It is interesting to note that no special mention is made in the contract of the voyageur to work in his trade; a tinsmith would be a highly valued addition to any fur trading post. It is also surprising he was not paid additional wages.
Archibald Norman McLeod, partner, for M'Tavish, M'Gillivrays& Co.
Louis Lafranchise of Faubourg St-Antoine (Montreal), blacksmith
Posts of the Northwest in Upper Canada
signed by Louis Lafranchis [sic]; signed by A.N. MacLeod
the voyageur receives an advance of 10 piastres; will receive 10 when leaving
as above. A blacksmith would be even more appreciated in a trading post.
Archibald Norman McLeod, partner, for M'Tavish, M'Gillivrays& Co.
Posts of the Northwest in Upper Canada
mark of Joseph Thouin; signed by A.N. MacLeod
the voyageur receives an advance of 8 piastres; will receive 8 when leaving
Archibald Norman McLeod, partner, for M'Tavish, M'Gillivrays& Co.
Posts of the Northwest in Upper Canada
mark of Pierre Lord; signed by A.N. MacLeod
the voyageur receives an advance of 8 piastres

as above. Would the additional mention of labourer (a term that would apply to nearly all voyageurs) imply that he was required to perform more than the usual tasks at the posts? If so, this is not stipulated in the contract.
Archibald Norman McLeod, partner, for M'Tavish, M'Gillivrays& Co.
Joseph Jannot (Jeannot) of La Rivière à la Graisse
Posts of the Northwest in Upper Canada
mark of Joseph Jeannot; signed by A.N. MacLeod
the voyageur receives an advance of 8 piastres; will receive 8 when leaving
as above for regular wintering contracts.

Archibald Norman McLeod, partner, for M'Tavish, M'Gillivrays& Co.
Posts of the Northwest in Upper Canada
marks of Louis Chevrette and Jos. Baudry; signed by A.N. MacLeod
the voyageur recognizes having received an advance of 215 livres; will receive 8 when leaving
as above. In this contract Chevrette takes the place of Joseph Baudry, who was hired in December 1819, obviously didnot do the voyage, and whose contract is hereby cancelled.
received double the usual equipment and 50 livres on account
This contract is for the XY Company
François Richard of Faubourg St. Laurent
Michilimackinac, obliged to continue to Sault Ste-Marieand, if so requested, around the lakes
received 10 piastres on account and will receive another12 piastres when leaving

Pierre de Rastel de Rocheblave, 1764-1840, fur traderfounding member of the XY Company. Rocheblave was given responsibility for the Voyageurs' Fund along with ThomasThain. (The Voyageur Fund was the earliest pension fund inCanada).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The 1999 Acquisition consists of 120 voyageur contracts (1801-1821). For complete listing and description, see the Appendix.

December 2001 Acquisitions

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized under three headings: Voyageur Contracts, Documents concerning the bankruptcy of the North West Company, and Canadian Fur Trade Documents.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The December 2001 Acquisitions consist of 17 voyageur contracts (1802-1821), 36 documents relating to the Canadian fur trade (1751-1822), and six documents relating to the bankruptcy of the North West Company (1826-1828).

scopecontent.p: The December 2003 Acquisition consists of three voyageur contracts (1808-1818), one document relating to a court judgement obtained by Joseph Sanguinet against Mathurin Laroche (1770), and three statements of account relating to the Canadian fur trade (1792-1796).
